She went on, "You know Melody, mom and dad were right; my old body looks just like a young version mom. I can't believe I never noticed that when I had it."

Well that was just great. Melody was absolutely right; like Amelia, Melody's body shared mom's coloring and Melody's body really did look like a clone of mom from her old childhood pictures. Unfortunately for me this meant that, in all likelihood, no matter how much growing up this body did, I'd never reach my old height. Of course, I reasoned, that probably wouldn't have been any different if I'd switched with Amelia, so at least that hadn't gotten any worse. Whereas I was looking at things through a lens mostly of resignation, Melody seemed to be in a state of mild elation. I'd rather expected that to have faded a bit once the switch actually happened, but apparently she really was just that excited to be older.

While I was paying attention to Melody, Gloria had been talking with mom. Normally I'd have been paying attention to that too, but I was having trouble focusing on more than one thing at a time. I'd tried to hold both things in my mind, but I'd stopped paying attention to mom and Gloria as soon as Melody had started talking to me. I didn't even realise that I'd tuned out mom and Gloria until mom started talking.

"Dr. Thomas has some things he wants to discuss with me alone before we leave, so I'm going to leave you two here while I go to his office. David," she looked at my old body, "keep an eye on your little sister while I'm gone."

"You got it mom," Melody responded as mom walked out towards Dr. Thomas' office.

"I no need babythitting! I owder den you!" I glowered at Melody

"Not anymore," responded my old body with a smile.

"Ith not funny!" I stamped my foot just like Melody used to do when she got frustrated. Stupid motor skills.

"I know, I know. I'm sorry Melody. This is just really cool for me. I'm a grown up. This is all I've ever wanted. I'm not trying to rub it in, I'm just really happy."

I knew she was telling the truth. Melody had never been the obnoxious sort and even though I'd never really known how to interact with her because of our age difference we'd always basically gotten along. It wasn't right for me to take this out on her.

"I sowwy too. Dis aww jutht vewy thtwange fow me."

"Wow, I never really noticed that lisp when I had it. I'm sorry you have to deal with that. So, how'd everything go with Dr. Thomas?"

"Good. He jutht wanted to do thome tethts wif me. Thomething wif cups of watew an' bwocks an' thuff."

"Yeah, he made me do those too. Twice actually, once before and once after. I felt really silly the second time realising that I'd answered wrong before."

She'd answered wrong the first time and right the second? Dr. Thomas hadn't said anything to me about right or wrong answers. Was he just trying to figure out if they'd accidentally left some of my knowledge in her brain? Maybe I could find out.

"What you do wong da fiwst time?"

Melody laughed, "lots of things. For example, even though I watched him pour the water from the short fat beaker into the tall one, I still said the tall beaker had more water in it."

"Da taww one did have mowe watew in it! It wath way highew!"

"Melody, he poured it straight out of the short, fat beaker into the tall one, it had to be the same amount."

"It wath highew! Dat meanth it wath mowe." I was sure of that. I'd seen it happen myself.

"Well then, let's just say I answered differently the second time." I nodded, appeased, and she continued, "I asked him if that meant I had your knowledge and he explained that the test didn't actually measure knowledge, but how rather how our brains were processing the world and that since I now had a teenager's brain, that meant I was processing the world like a teenager would and not like a four-year-old would."

Thank goodness. They hadn't actually left my knowledge in my old body. I did wonder why Melody thought she'd been wrong the first time but I decided to let it slide. There wasn't much reasoning with a four-year-old, after all.

I was about to ask her how she though her friends would react to all of this when mom came back into the lobby carrying a small binder.

"Wath da bindew fow?"

"It's just some paperwork for mommy and daddy, nothing for little girls to worry about."

"How about teenage boys?" Melody realised just a bit too late that her enthusiasm might not have been in the best taste, "Sorry Melody, I didn't mean..."

"Ith OK, I know you twying." I gave him a hug to reassure him, slightly surprised that I'd just mentally referred to Melody as "him".

Mom held my hand as we walked out to the car and then Melody lifted me into what was now my car seat, strapping me in snugly.

"Ith too tight. I can't weach anything."

"I'm sorry hon," mom said, "that's how it's supposed to be. Child safety laws and all that." Mom closed my door and then got into the passenger seat as Melody got in on the driver's side.

"Mommy! He no can dwive!" Great, not only did Melody's speech processing destroy my grammar, it was making me use "mommy" when I tried to say "mom."

"Yes I can!" Melody's comment was excitement, not protest. "Dr. Thomas said that driving ability should have stayed with the body like other motor skills and he was right. Mom and I took a test run around the parking lot while you were still in the recovery room and it all just came to me. It was so cool!"

And so we were heading back home. I'd like to say that I remembered more of the drive, but Melody, like many young children, tended to fall asleep in a moving car and that non-conscious response, on top of the long day, meant I was soon snoozing peacefully, strapped firmly into my booster seat.
1123111111.title: Meeting the new David

11231111111.content:
I woke to mom unbuckling me from my car seat in our driveway.

"Wake up Melody, we're home now. It's time to go in and see your father and your sister."

"OK mommy," I yawned.

"Here mom, I'll carry her in for you," Melody offered. Before I had a chance to protest, my old body had lifted me out of the car seat and hefted me onto its shoulders.

"I always liked it when dad gave me a piggyback ride," Melody said, "I thought you might enjoy it now too." With that, she carried me into the house.

Melody had been right in her assumption too. I found that being up high like that was a lot of fun and even though I remembered being tall before, it seemed that Melody's instinctive responses still found this a novelty. I found myself smiling happily as she set me down on the living room couch in front of the rest of the family.

"Thank you David." I said, remembering what Gloria had told me about making sure to use the right names for our new bodies.

Cassie came over and sat down between Melody and me, seemingly unsure of whom she was supposed to comfort while Amelia just looked happy that she'd managed to avoid the whole thing. Dad broke the silence.

"I saw David getting out of the driver's side of the car. Were they not able to perform the switch today or something?"

Melody spoke up excitedly, "It turns out that motor skills and instinctive things stay with the body! So not only am I grown up now, I can drive! It's really cool!"

"Not fow me," I grumbled. "I can't even wead anymowe."

Amelia giggled, "Awww, poor nerd can't read his comic books. Guess it's dollies for you now."

"AMELIA!" Thankfully dad didn't share Amelia's sense of humor, but even though he'd gotten Amelia to shut up, she was still wearing an expression containing entirely too much amusement.

Dad turned back to me, "so that's really you in there David?"

"Yeth daddy." Amelia stifled a giggle and mom gave her a stern look as I continued. "Da doctow thaid dat thing wike wanguage pwocething an' motow thkiww an' thtuff thtay wif da owd body. Tho I thtuck tawking wike Mewody now."

Dad looked thoughtful, and Cassie just hugged me.

"Apparently the ability to perform logical manipulation on new information and to process the immediate world around them also stayed with the old bodies," mom added, looking through the binder that Dr. Thomas had given her. "It says here that even though David still remembers everything he's learned, we should expect him to only be able to process new information like a 4-year-old would, while Melody should now have the logical skills of a 16-year-old."

My stomach was beginning to rumble a bit and I realised that neither Melody nor I had eaten since breakfast. "I hungwy. Can we have dinnew now? Pwease?"

"Yeah," Melody agreed, "we haven't had anything to eat since breakfast."

I think mom had noticed Amelia's thinly disguised mirth too, because she quickly agreed, suggesting that it might help us all take our minds off of things.

As we headed to the kitchen table, Cassie finally spoke, "Don't worry Dav-- uh, Melody, it won't be so bad. You and I will still get to hang out, I promise."

Thank heaven for small favors.
11231111111.title: Back Home

The family's out, but Laura's there to babysit
112311111111.content:
Waking up the next morning in Melody's room was an odd mix of disconcerting and comforting. The room certainly didn't match my memories (and I definitely could have done without all the ultra-girlie decorations that resulted from Melody and Amelia sharing a room), but at the same time Melody's instinctive reaction to being tucked tightly into bed under a thick comforter was apparently one of substantial reassurance. I felt safe and disoriented all at the same time. Surreal to say the least.

The disorientation passed quickly enough though as I ran through yesterday once more in my mind. Dinner had been more of an adventure (and more embarrassing) than I'd anticipated, but at the time I asked all I'd been able to concentrate on was the fact that I was hungry. Apparently a 4-year-old's mind didn't really do multitasking.

Dad had made stuffed peppers, one of my favorites, along with a bowl of macaroni and cheese (the kind with cartoon character shapes for the pasta) for Melody, who had always thought that the stuffed peppers were "ucky," and I was happy to see that he'd at least put the stuffed pepper in front of me (even if it was pre-cut into bite-size pieces), giving the new David the macaroni, which he was looking at thougtfully for some reason. I was less happy about the sippy cup at my place setting.

"I not weawwy tho widdle! Can I pwease have a weguwaw cup?" My childish voice and lisp didn't really help make my protest terribly believable, but I think Amelia's giggling actually convinced mom to acquiesce.

I smiled smugly at Amelia as mom changed out the sippy cup for a regular cup, though I did notice the new cup, in addition to being only half-full, was plastic and not glass like everyone else's. Still, things felt like a victory so far.

Which was when it had all fallen apart, of course.

Melody's body's lack of coordination made it a bit awkward getting the bit of stuffed pepper onto my fork, and the impression I had that everyone was watching me hadn't helped, but I was soon able to work it out, eager to have a bite of my favorite dinner. As soon as I got the morsel to my mouth though, I realised something was wrong.

"Dat's ucky!" I exclaimed, making a face and immediately spitting out the barely chewed bit of stuffed pepper. I was sure that dad had screwed up the recipe somehow since everyone had been so busy watching me that none of them had taken a bite yet. "It not taste wight!"

David, however, appeared to think for a moment, "Melody, can I try some of your stuffed pepper?"

"You no wike thuffed peppews," I replied with as much of a matter-of-fact tone as I could muster.

"I just want to test something, OK?" Mom and dad were watching with clear interest, as was Amelia. Cassie just seemed bemused by the entire situation.

"I thuppothe," I gave in as David reached over to spear a portion of stuffed pepper off my plate, "but daddy made dem wong. Dey ucky."

David just shrugged and popped the food into his mouth, chewing thoughtfully for a second before swallowing.

"Wow! These are amazing!" I was shocked, but out of the corner of my eye I noticed Amelia nodding for some reason. It didn't make sense to me, but then David continued. "I thought so. Our taste preferences must have stayed with our old bodies too. I wondered about that as soon as dad gave me the macaroni."

I was a bit stunned, but it made perfect sense now that the logical steps had been explained to me. After all, taste preferences were instinctive phenomena. I wondered why I hadn't been able to make that connection, but was soon distracted by David switching plates with me. Without thinking, I reached out to take a big drink of my milk and get the taste of the pepper out of my mouth.

And understood why Melody still got a sippy cup at dinner as I fumbled with the cup and ended up with most of the contents onto my lap.

Mom had cleaned me up and dinner had gone OK from there, though I was stuck with the "kiddie meal" and a sippy cup for the remainder. I'd tried not to think too much about the thoughtful look that Amelia wore for the rest of the meal.

After dinner Amelia had gotten ready for some sleep-over with her friend Alexandra, so to stay out of her way I'd hung out in my old room with Cassie and David.

"So you really expected to like the stuffed peppers, Melody?" Cassie had still seemed curious about everything that had happened at dinner.

"Yeth. I 'membew wiking dem befowe."

"And you didn't think that taste preferences might have stayed with your old body?"

"I.. I didn't weawwy think about it..."

"Yeah," David had cut in, "it was weird for me too. The thought just sort of popped into my brain. It was really cool, actually. I used to have to really try to think all the steps through but here it just sort of happened all in the background. Being grown up is really cool!"

I'd sighed and David backpedaled a bit, "Uh, sorry Melody."

"Ith OK. You gonna hafta learn a whowe buncha thtuff fow thchool dat I awweady know, tho dewe awe thome things dat awe good fow me." Without thinking I stuck my tongue out at him, blushing a bit when I realised how childish the gesture was.

"Oh, I'll bet that Dr. Thomas has a way to..." David suddenly trailed off as, unbeknownst to me, Cassie was gesturing behind my back for him to stop.

"Doctow Thomas hath a way to what?"

"Nothing, it wasn't important"

"Awe you thure?"

"So," Cassie broke in, interrupting my train of thought and effectively distracting me from following up on what David had meant, "what was in the binder that mom brought back?"

"I dunno. Dey thaid it wathn't thomething I thould wowwy about." I'd already forgotten about mom reading from the binder about the test results.

"Probably just some legal papers then," Cassie replied, giving David a look suggesting that he should stay quiet. "You and I should talk sometime soon, Melody, just us girls, without this silly boy hanging around."

Cassie's smile and laugh were enough to coax a small giggle from me too, especially since I'd wanted a chance to talk with her alone as well. Unfortunately, about that time, mom came in and announced that it was my bedtime, carrying me off to make sure I brushed my teeth and got myself ready.

Yup, yesterday had certainly been eventful, I thought as I struggled a bit to free myself from the tightly tucked sheets and got myself dressed in Melody's clothes. I did wish that she hadn't been so obsessed with Disney movies as I pulled on a Tinkerbell t-shirt and made my way downstairs.
112311111111.title: Waking up in Melody's bed

1123111111111.content:
Heading out of the room I now shared with Amelia, I noticed that the upstairs seemed empty. Apparently everyone else had gotten up before me. I'd tried to check the time on Amelia's alarm clock before leaving the room, but even that digital clock didn't make sense to me now. Looking out the window, the bright sky and only moderately long shadows made me guess that it was at least 10 am, which felt a little weird since I was used to being one of the first people up in the morning.

When I reached the top of the stairs I could hear voices in the family room below and realised that Stephen and Laura must have come over to meet the new me. Wonderful, I thought to myself. Still, it wasn't going to get any easier the longer I waited and I started down the stairs.

"There's my little sis!" Melody exclaimed as I walked into the room to see them sitting on the couch with the TV on.

Stephen turned to look at me and stifled a laugh.

"Wath tho funny?"

"Chose that shirt yourself, did you?"

"Ith jutht Tinkewbeww. Da gween wath bettew dan pink."

"Yeah, but 'Pixie Princess'? Really?"

I looked down at my shirt. Apparently those were't just squiggly decorations...

"It not my fauwt Mewody can't wead." I looked down a little embarrassed, as Laura walked over to me and bent down to my level, hands between her knees in the way that adults tended to do when they were trying to be non-intimidating to small children.

"Your brother was telling us about how instinctive things stayed with the old body," she said, nodding towards my old body, "but I'm still not sure you're not playing a trick on us... Tell you what, I'm going to ask you some questions that I know Melody doesn't know the answer to and we'll see if you can answer them. OK?"

I just nodded figuring that the sooner we got this over the sooner we could have something like a normal conversation.

"What's ten times ten?"

"One hunned."

"That was an easy one, how about thirty-two times eight?"

"Uh..." I struggled. I knew exactly what I was supposed to do, but for some reason I was having a lot of trouble getting my brain to actually do it. "Dath eight gwoupth of thiwty-two aww togeddew..." No matter how hard I tried, I just couldn't keep enough in my head at the same time to get the answer. "I dunno," I admitted in defeat.

Laura looked thoughtful for a moment and then continued. "OK, let's try something different, what's wrong with Mass Effect 3?"

"Da ending thuckth!" I answered immediately, "no mattew what you do in da game ith aww jutht da thame thing in diffewent cowouws!"

"And if I said that my new computer had a 486 in it?"

"Den you'd be thupid 'cause a 486 not new. Awe we done now?" This was a little annoying but mostly I was concerned about not having been able to answer the second math question.

Laura nodded and walked back over to the couch, patting the seat next to her to suggest that I should come over too. I headed over and obliged her.

"Tho, you bewieve uth now?"

"Yup. How about you Stephen?"

Stephen nodded too, a slightly bemused look on his face. "Laura, why do you think David couldn't answer the 32 times 8 question?"

I spoke up, "Dath a good question. An' caww me Mewody now; I hafta get uthed to it thometime."

Laura pondered the question for a moment, "I'll bet is has to do with all the instinctive stuff that Mel - er, David," she nodded towards my old body, "was telling us about earlier. Melody here," she patted me on the head and I scowled a little, "clearly remembered what multiplication was, she just couldn't make the more complex manipulations happen in her 4-year-old brain. Some of math is memorization, that's how she got the first question right, but a lot of it is being able to manipulate information and a little kid's brain doesn't have the neural connections to do that yet. So even though she knows the concept of multiplication and can do math that's simple memorization, like multiplying by ten, her brain isn't developed enough yet to perform anything more complex than reciting answers she's basically just memorized."

I tried to follow Laura's explanation, but had a difficult time. Not because I didn't understand what she was saying, but because my attention kept drifting to the TV that was in front of me now that I was sitting on the couch.
1123111111111.title: Stephen and Laura are over and talking with Mel...

11231111111111.content:
"Dith bowing!" I found myself exclaiming, just like Melody used to do when there wasn't enough going on to keep her stimulated. She'd been a typically active child and, like most 4-year-olds didn't have the longest attention span.

Stephen looked at me oddly, but then smiled, "How about we have a go a few rounds on Killzone 2? Maybe I can be the one saving your ass now."

"You'we on, thtupid-head. An' ith Kiwwzone twee. Dewe no spwit-scween in Kiwwzone two." I retorted, mildly embarrassed that my insult had apparently gone through the same "Melody-speak" translation that everything else that came out of my mouth went through. The fact that I'd stuck my tongue out afterwards didn't make me feel any better.

Laura and Melody stifled a giggle and I shot them a glare as best I could with my current body's cherubic features as we trooped up to what used to be my bedroom and Stephen booted up the PS3 and brought up the loading screen.

"OK squirt, let's get started." Stephen's use of his nickname for Melody as he tossed me a controller annoyed me and even though I was struggling to find a grip with my much smaller hands I vowed to show him up like I always did.

It didn't work out.

Melody's body lacked the coordination and muscle memory to handle the controller well and my character mostly careened around the map as though he were drunk. I still had the experience to know what was coming in the game and what I needed to do, but that only made my ineptitude with the controller all the more frustrating. On top of that, the whole game seemed to be moving faster than I rememberd it. My child's brain was strugging to keep up with the flow of the game and failing pretty miserably.

After my fifth time accidentally killing Stephen's characted because I couldn't tell the difference between his character and the enemy I threw down my controller in disgust. "Dis game thtupid!"

Melody, however had been watching intently, "You mind if I try?"

"Sure thing, David." Even though I'd asked him to call us by the names appropriate for our bodies, I still found myself a little annoyed at Stephen calling Melody by my name.

I watched the two of them play for a bit and was surprised to see that Melody was doing better than I had been. Sure, she was a bit un-coordinated, but she kept getting a little better as they continued playing and she definitely wasn't having the sort of trouble keeping up with what was going on in the game that I had been having.

I was getting increasingly agitated by Melody's newfound ability when Laura grabbed my hand.

"Hey, how about we leave these two to their little game and go have a talk?"
11231111111111.title: Stephen suggests a couple rounds of Killzone 2 ...

112311111111111.content:
I just nodded and let Laura lead me out of the room, trying not to wince too much as Stephen congratulated Melody on yet another "good shot."

Still irritated at the loss of an ability that had been a large part of my life, I didn't notice the somewhat clinical look Laura gave me as she walked me out to our backyard swingset and sat me down on one of the swings. Setting herself down on the other, she studied me for a moment before jumping in.

"If you keep letting things bother you that much, you're only going to make it harder on yourself you know." Laura's tone was casual as she looked straight ahead.

I just looked down and sighed.

"Look, you knew this had to happen to help your family, right? And regardless, there's no way to undo what's been done, right?" Her tone had shifted into matter-of-fact as she turned to look at me.

"I know, but ith hard! I twy thtuff an' I'm thtuck wif Mewody's wittle kid abiwities. I don wike da thame foods, I can't wead my bookth no mowe - I can't even tawk wight no mowe. An ith aww worthe 'cuz I 'membew how I uthed to be able ta'do thtuff but I can't no mowe!" The words just pour out of me and it's all I can do to keep from crying thanks to the emotional reactions of my child brain.

I hang my head in my hands and don't notice that Laura's moved until I feel her wrapping me up in her arms. "It's OK David," her use of my old name is comforting, "think about it this way. You've made probably a hundred different RPG characters in all of your gaming, right?"

I just nodded, letting her keep holding me and enjoying the comfort from that.

"OK, and you don't always make them the same, right? You build them differently and use different skills and interact with the world differently, right? You'd have to be stupid to play the new character the same way as the old character, right?"

Again, I just nod, staying tight against Laura.

"And when you start a new character they don't have very good skills and you have to work hard to level them up and it takes a while if you're not just grinding, right?"

More nodding.

"So just think of all this as you having a chance to start a new character. Yeah, you're going to have to deal with being lower level for a while, but it's a chance to play the game in a whole different way. Maybe if you stop trying to play it the same way you've always played it you'll be less stressed?"

I stopped and looked up at Laura, the concern clear in her eyes. When it came right down to it, she was right. If I kept trying to be David in Melody's body I was just going to make things horrible. Melody certainly wasn't trying to be her same old self and she was handling things much better than I was. Granted, that was probably easier to do when you'd gained a bunch of abilities than when you'd lost them, but that didn't change the fact that fighting reality was just going to make it worse.

"I gueth you'we wight, Wauwa. But I don't hafta wike it wight now..."

"Just promise me you'll give it a try, OK? Don't try to be David or Melody. Sit down and think about the best way to manage your new character and be that person. Try it for a week? As a favor?"

I sighed, I couldn't think of a good reason not to and I knew Laura was really smart and not likely to mess with me like Stephen might. "I'ww twy." I promised her. "But onwy if you no teww Stephen an' David dat I wet you hug me wike dat."

Laura smiled and nodded.

1123111111112.content:
Once I made my way downstairs, I realized that my family didn't seem to be in sight. Before I could react however, a pair of arms suddenly swooped me off the floor.

"Wow, you're a lot lighter than I remember David" said a familiar voice, "And you were a few inches taller than me the last time we met"

"LAUWA!!!" I exclaim loudly, wrapping my tiny arms around Laura's neck. For some reason, it felt really nice being held in her arms - even if it was that I was literally being held in her arms.

"My my, you've shrunk so much, David" Laura playfully teased.

"Akulawe, yu hav to caw me Mewodie nou" I say, "docdews towd me and Dabid to refew to eachwozer by ze ozerz wamez"

"and it looks like you even got Melody's lisp with that body" Laura noted

"I na.." I say. However now that I think about it - "Whar iz ewy bodi?" I ask, wanting to know where my family was?

"Well Da.. I mean 'Melody', your family wanted to go over the basics of 'being big' with 'David', so the whole family is out" Laura answers

"Buh wi aw you her?"

"To babysit you silly" Laura cues. That's right, Laura would always come over to my house to babysit Melody when Mom and Dad weren't around. She would especially bring her little sister Brittany over to play since she and Melody were good play mates/friends. It never really occurred to me until now that I would now be the one being babysat by Laura and playing with Brittany. And as far as Brittany is concerned, since Laura was sworn to secrecy regarding the swap operation, I was the same old Melody she always played with, and not David. "You know, now that you're in Melody's body, even though this feels a little different it also feels as though nothing has really changed" Laura notes, regarding my lisp and mannerisms in display.

"owkwa, owkwa, I cet it" I whine. Laura continued to chuckle a bit at how much like Melody I was acting like despite actually being David... trapped inside this body.... But soon my tummy rumbles. "Im hungwy" I say to Laura

"Well let's get you something to eat then" Laura responds, placing me into the toddler table seat. I await, sitting idly in the table seat, as I watch Laura prepare me a bowl of cereal. It got me thinking about how my friendship with Laura ever since she moved into town 2 years ago. Despite being a year younger than me and Stephen at the time, we quickly became accustomed to one another. While she would try to spend a lot more time with my sister Cassandra, her being the only other girl in our group, she would tend to spend the most time with me.... and if I am being honest... I had been hoping.. maybe... ask her out.... but now that isn't possible anymore with me stuck in this little body.

Once Laura set the bowl of cereal in front of me, I was almost ready to try to grab the spoon the best I could. But then Laura grabbed the spoon before I could reach it. And then...

"Oops, sorry 'Melody'" Laura says while I almost choke on the cereal (not really actually, just was startled by the action, that's all). "I almost forgot that you were more used to feeding yourself. You just look and act so much like Melody did now"

"Yu guzt mez me wike thiz" I retort once I swallow the cereal

"Still, it's almost hard to tell that you and your little sister had ever swapped bodies"

Laura kind of had a point, after all if even Dad is still coming to terms with this having happened it shouldn't have been a surprised that Laura is the same. I simply smile at Laura, almost as if I was telling her that "it was ok", and ready myself for then next spoonful of cereal Laura prepares for me. I did feel awkward about having to be spoonfed again, as it was yet another reminder of the independence I had as a teenage boy being lost to me now. At the same time however, it was honestly kind of nice having someone else feed me while I could just sit idly with ease, simple opening my mouth, close, chew, swallow, and then open again. I could see why Melody had always been so carefree - I wonder if she might have realized what she had given away to be in my body.

With the bowl of cereal now empty, Laura gently wiped any milk or crumbs that might have gotten on my face and hoisted me out of the table seat. Having been set back on the floor, I give Laura the best hug I possibly could around her legs.

"Are you sure that's really David in there" Laura teased. I look up at Laura, still astonished by how much she towers me now.

"Cawd yu.. nod tweet mwe too muj wike a 4 wew owd?.." I shyly say to Laura, stepping back. "I still wanna remain friends with you... please don't go" I was thinking to myself. As though she could read my mind, Laura knelt down so that we would be at eye level - mostly.

"Don't worry, we're still friends, David" she assures me, referring to me by "David" instead of "Melody" to make her point across. I smile back as to tell her "Thank you". Again, as though she was reading my mind, Laura playfully jests that I didn't have to worry about my saying thank you sounding too embarrassing in the lisp.

Another thing comes to my mind. "Iz.. Bwittani comin two?" I ask

It's Amelia, with an obnoxious look on her face.
112311111112.content:
Before long, Mom was serving us all... spaghetti again, just like the day this all started. I wondered if that was a deliberate choice, but I didn't say anything.

An awkward silence prevailed throughout the meal, but my futile attempts to get the spaghetti in my mouth without spilling were clearly the centre of attention. Melody watched me with interest, fascinated at seeing her clumsy old self from the outside. Amelia just kept smirking at me; I shot her a glare now and then, but that didn't discourage her in the least. And Cassandra was giving me a look of sympathy, clearly wondering how best to comfort me.

Mom and Dad, meanwhile, were trying not to stare so blatantly. Dad instead focused his curious gaze on Melody, seemingly still finding it hard to believe the swap had actually happened.

Once we were done eating, Melody turned to me. "Say, Melody... want to play a game?"

I stared at him. Her. Whatever. "Uhhh..."

"What's wrong? Scared of losing?" Melody teased.

"Weww... yeth, actuawwy." The idea of losing to Melody at something I'd spent so much time on was not appealing. I couldn't see Amelia, but I knew she would be finding that funny.

"Cm'on, it'll be fun!" My old body took off, and I followed it to the stairs. The gigantic stairs.

"Dey tho taww..." I muttered.

"Come on, you can do it! I should know!" Melody said cheerfully.

I slowly hefted myself up the stairs, enviously watching Melody stomp rapidly upwards, before following her into my old room. I approached the bed and stared at it until, without warning, Melody picked me up from behind. I involuntarily giggled a little before she set me down atop the sheets. Well, at least I was enjoying one thing about this.

I watched Melody fumble around with the PS3 for a few seconds before turning it on and starting up Call of Duty. Part of me wanted to protest; that wasn't something little girls should be playing. But of course, I was the little girl now, and I already knew a lot of things little girls shouldn't. So I bit my tongue. Still, it occurred to me that Melody was going to have to learn a lot of things rather quickly in the coming weeks. She was happy now, but it wouldn't be all sunshine and roses for her.

"Here ya go." Melody plopped down a controller in front of me. I tried to wrap my little hands around it, but there was no way I could have all the buttons in reach at once. This was going to be difficult.

"Ith too big," I complained in a whinier tone than I intended.

"I know, right? You'll manage. You're the one who actually knows how to play this." Melody was aimlessly wandering the game's menu. I recognised the screen she was on, but the text was meaningless to me now. Being illiterate was getting old fast.

"Can you weawwy wead dat?" I asked. Sure, Melody had my ability to process the words, but could she actually understand them?

"I don't think it's as easy for me as it was for you, but yeah. You just look at the letters and put their sounds together to make words. It's funny, it never really made sense to me before." That didn't sound like stellar reading skills, but it was more than I could manage now.

As Melody kept exploring the menu, my gaze wandered to the pin-up poster on the wall. I'd always thought that girl was hot, so it was surreal to look at her now and feel nothing, my new body not even being capable of arousal. Heck, it was hard to even grasp the concept of "attractive" now. Obviously, sexuality would be another thing that wasn't transferred. Rather than give much thought to the disturbing ramifications of that, I simply added it to my list of reasons this was better than being Amelia.

Eventually, Melody managed to initiate a one-on-one match between us. The ensuing shootout was... interesting. Melody had taken my dexterity and muscle memory, leaving me struggling to work the controller, but as she'd said, I was still the one who knew the game. So I compensated for my awkward, clumsy movement with my knowledge of the map, good use of cover and other smart tactics. It was like a contest between my body and my mind, and it was actually quite thrilling. For a while, our scores kept close.

In the end, though, I wasn't able to think fast enough to keep up, and once Melody caught on to my tricks, she pulled ahead and ended up winning.

"Phooey," I childishly spat at the game's end, gently throwing my controller down.

"Hey, you did good for a little girl." Melody smiled.

"Not funny!"

"It's not just a joke, though. Remember, you might've lost a lot, but you still make a great four-year-old."

Grumbling, I leapt off the bed and headed for the door.

"You going to your room, Melody?" asked the boy I still thought of as Melody. "I'll leave you alone now. I think you want some time to yourself."

That was true enough. I still hadn't had much time to really contemplate my situation... although I wasn't sure if I wanted to. As I left the room, I glanced at a stack of comics and cursed my illiteracy again. If I was going to keep up with my comics now, I'd need someone to read them to me. One of many demeaning experiences to look forward to.

I approached the door to Melody's room, now my room, reached up and pulled the door handle down. As I pushed the door open and went inside, I found my expected solitude denied by someone sitting on my new bed.
112311111112.title: Little gamer girl

1123111111121.content:
Cassie was sitting on the bed, holding open the binder Mom had earlier. "Oh, here you are," she said.

"Hewwo, Cathie," I slurred. She gave me a look of slight pity before turning her attention to the binder again.

"I was just looking at the notes about the tests they did with you. It's... interesting stuff." She paused, nervously taking a breath. "The way Melody's... the old Melody's... results changed after the swap is really crazy."

I thought back to what Melody had said about the test with the beakers of water, and how she'd answered differently the second time. But she'd been right the first time... hadn't she?

I hesitantly decided to mention it. "Wike wif da beakews?"

"Yeah... before the switch she couldn't tell they were the same, but then... oh." She stopped herself and assumed a panicked expression as she noticed something else on the page. "A-and you..."

My heart sank. Cassie was against me on this?

"N-no..." My voice trembled. "No, Mewo..." I couldn't keep calling her that. "David wath wight da firtht time!"

Cassie looked pained. "...Melody. It was the same amount of water."

"...No! No, it wath tawwer! It... it.." I trailed off as I realised with creeping horror I had to be wrong. I hadn't trusted Melody's judgement, but...

"Cathie... I twust you. If you thay I wong, den..."

I hung my head, and we both fell silent. I replayed the test in my head, trying to understand my error. I began to see how my answer couldn't have been right, but I couldn't quite wrap my head around the logic.

"Aaah! It doethn't make thenthe!" I suddenly yelled. "It... how could... I dun'..."

"Shhh... it's okay..." Cassie cooed. "Listen... Melody... I'm sorry I brought this up. I shouldn't be stressing you out like this." She closed the binder and put it down.

"Ith okay..." Holding back tears, I looked up at her. "Cathie... you jutht... dunno what to thay to me, do you?"

"Yeah, you got me," she sighed. "I mean, what on Earth do you say to your 16-year-old brother who just became your 4-year-old sister?"

That earned a nervous little chuckle from me. This really was absurd.

"Seriously, though," she continued, "I know this must be hard for you, and... I just want you to know I'm here for you..."

I was feeling very emotional at this point. I was tempted to blame it on Melody's instincts, but really, I had every right to be overwhelmed. I gave Cassie a hug... or at least, gave her leg a hug. "I wuv you, thith."

"Aww, I wuv you too, Melody." She paused. "I'm sorry. I'm treating you like a kid now..."

To my surprise, I was actually a little disappointed to hear that. I looked away and summoned the courage to speak my mind.

"Yanno what? You can tweat me wike a kid if you wanna. Ith... ith comfowting." I weakly smiled at Cassie before quickly adding, "But dun' teww anyone I said dat. 'thpethiawwy not Amewia."

"Your secret's safe with me, little sis." Cassie said, ruffling my hair. I smiled again, more easily this time. Anyone else doing the same would have annoyed me, at least if they knew who I was, but now I was beginning to feel I could open up to Cassie and be honest about what my hybrid mind was making me feel.
1123111111121.title: Sisterly love

11231111111212.content:
"By the way," Cassie said, "Amelia was here before me. I chased her off for you."

"Oh. Thank you. Keep doin' dat. I no wanna be thtuck awone wit' hew."

"Of course you don't. Who would?"

I giggled quietly.

I spent the remaining daytime just sort of relaxing with Cassie. The fact that she had already gotten along with both me and Melody helped us get over the initial awkwardness. Occasionally she almost seemed to forget who I actually was, but as long as no-one else was around I didn't feel the need to complain.

The next day, I awoke to the sound of Mom's voice. "Melody, honey! It's time you were up!"

Right, that was me now. I sat up, opened my eyes to the sight of Melody's bed, and drowsily looked down at my pajama-clad little arms. Yep, I was still Melody. Having calmly confirmed that, I stretched my arms and yawned.

"Good mowning, Mommy," I said.

Mom smiled, probably pleasantly surprised that I wasn't saying something about it not being a dream. "Feeling alright? Good. Get yourself dressed and come down for breakfast."

She left the room. I got out of bed and started looking through Melody's clothes. Most of the available outfits involved some kind of skirt, something I would rather avoid. It didn't really seem wrong to wear one, but dammit, I wasn't about to throw my old self away entirely. I may have begun to accept being a kid again, but no way was I going to be a girly girl.

Eventually I settled on a T-shirt and a pair of overalls, which I didn't think Melody had worn in a while. I went down the stairs, feeling a little scared of falling, and entered the kitchen. Mom, standing by the counter, greeted me with a smile. She picked me up and put me in my place at the table. Dad and Melody were already eating, but Cassie and Amelia were conspicuously absent.

"Good morning, little sis!" Melody cheerfully greeted me.

"Mowning, bwuddah," I replied with far less enthusiasm.

"Mmm. It's good to see you two adjusting," Dad said.

"Alright, Melody, here's your breakfast!" Mom announced. Before I knew what was happening, she jammed a spoonful of cereal in my mouth. I nearly choked.

"Oh, sorry, were you not ready?" she asked. "Sorry, but like your dad said, you're doing a good job adjusting already. It's kind of easy to forget."

I could understand that. The idea that "David" and I had been each other before the previous day couldn't be easy for anyone to accept. Still, it was a bit embarrassing that my own family could take me for the girl I looked like even when they knew better.

Melody noticed my discomfort as I swallowed the cereal. "Hey, just relax. It's nice to have things done for you, isn't it? You don't have to worry about anything."

If that was really her thinking, she wouldn't have been so eager to switch in the first place. Then again, maybe she just didn't appreciate what she had until she lost it. In any case, her words did make me feel better. So I sat peacefully and let Mom feed me.

Almost immediately after we were done, Cassie and Amelia entered the room.

"Hey, guys," Cassie said to Melody and I. "I've already talked to Mom about what we're going to do today."

Amelia looked at the empty bowl in front of me. "Hey, girlie, I see you've had your cereal. Did your mommy help you with that?"

Cassie briefly glared at Amelia before addressing me. "Don't worry, Melody. You and I are going out today, and mean ol' Amelia can't come, okay?"

I resisted the urge to stick my tongue out at Amelia. That was when I realised she was having the opposite effect from Cassie, making me cling to my pride for fear of encouraging her mockery. Our little feud would have to stop at some point. Hopefully she would relent before I did.

"Oh! I wanna go too!" Melody piped up.

"I think not, young man," Mom said. "You're going to spend today learning some of the things a 16-year-old should know."

"Aww, Mom! Can't I enjoy myself a little first?"

"We can't trust you on your own yet," Dad said. "We need to teach you some things before we can let you run around."

Melody sighed and looked at me with a tinge of jealousy. I considered making several different comments, but decided it was best to stay quiet.

"Are you ready to go now, Melody?" Cassie asked. "Dad gave us plenty of spending money, so you can get all the new things you want!"

"That's right," Dad confirmed. "We owe you two for all the money we'll be getting soon, so the least we can do is let you use some of it to make yourselves comfortable."

"Awwight, wet's go den," I said, hopping off my chair. I was a little apprehensive about facing the world as a little girl, but I didn't want to just sit around all day.

Cassie took my hand, enveloping it within her own. "Okay, sis! We can do whatever you want, okay?"

Amelia raised an eyebrow at Cassie's sweet tone. "Hey, how come she gets to baby you?"

I was a little taken aback by that. I began to formulate a response along the lines of "she's nice and you're a jerk", but Cassie intervened with a simpler solution: "Shut up, Amelia."

With that, Cassie and I made our way out. "You two have fun!" Mom shouted as we left the house.

"So! Where to, little sis?" Cassie asked once we were outside.

Two things came to mind. Firstly, I wanted to change my wardrobe. Picking my own clothes would be a good first step toward taking over Melody's life and making it my own. Second, I needed to introduce my new self to Stephen and Laura. It would be immensely awkward, of course, and I was dreading it, but I didn't want to put it off and grow distant from them. Plus, I'd rather Melody didn't get to them to before I did.
11231111111212.title: A day out with big sis

112311111112122.content:
"I, uh... I wanna thee Thtephen an' Waura," I said after some hesitation.

"Oh? Are you sure you're ready for that?" Cassie asked.

"I no wanna put it off."

"Yeah, that's probably wise... okay, I'll give Laura a call..."

Cassie took out her cell phone and dialled. I nervously listened to her half of the ensuing conversation.

"Hey, Laura. ... Yeah. Yeah, they've done it. ... Yep. ... Pretty well, actually. ... Yeah. ... I'm with Melody now, she wants to meet up. ... Yes. ... Yes, exactly. ... Uh-huh. ... Okay..."

Cassie kneeled down and held the phone to my ear. "She wants to talk to you."

"Uh, hewwo, Waura," I said.

"David!" came Laura's voice from the phone. "Is that really you?"

"Weww, I no David anymowe..."

"So this has really happened? I can hardly believe you went through with it." She paused. "Hey, David..."

"Mewody," I reluctantly corrected her.

"What's nine times five?"

"Fowty-five," I answered in a slightly annoyed tone.

"And what's thirteen times fourteen?"

"Uhh... a hunnerd eighty-two."

"Right! And... what's ninety-six times pi?"

"Thut up."

"Ha! Okay, that's convincing enough. But we ought to be speaking in person, right? My parents are away right now, so come and meet me at my house. I'll call Stephen over as well. See you soon!" She hung up.

"Well?" Cassie asked, standing up and putting her phone away.

"We gonna meet at hew houthe," I relayed. "Hew pawents out."

"Her parents? Okay, but what about Brittany?"

I froze up. I had totally forgotten about Laura's five-year-old sister. Brittany was a precocious kid, but she was also about as girly as they came. And I wouldn't put it past Laura to leave me at her mercy in the name of helping me adjust.

"She didn't mention Brittany, did she?" Cassie asked with an amused sigh, seeing the tension on my face.

"Aww, ith a twap!" I moaned.

"Heh, you think so? Well, Brittany is just another person you shouldn't put off meeting, right? And it's not like Laura won't want to spend time with you herself."

I sighed. Yes, interacting with other little girls was something I had to do now. And although I'd never seen much of Brittany, I knew she and Melody were close friends. I'd feel guilty if I refused to spend time with her.

"Well, come on, let's go." Cassie took my hand, and we started walking down the street.

After a longer time than the journey usually took, Cassie was knocking on the door of Laura's house. Laura answered immediately.

I stared up at her. She was huge. That shouldn't have been surprising, of course - everyone was huge. But it was still jarring to see Laura from this perspective for the first time. I would surely feel the same way when Stephen showed up.

"Hello, Cassie," Laura smiled. She looked down at me. "And... Melody. So, how are you feeling?"

"Weawwy thmaww," I answered.

"I can imagine. Um, are you speaking like that on purpose, or...?"

"I no can hewp it," I muttered.

"Interesting...!" Laura commented, weakly attempting to hide her enthusiasm. Though she was trying to be sympathetic, she was clearly eager to learn all about the effects of the swap.

"Laura, who's that?" came Brittany's voice from her room. Oh boy. She emerged into the hallway clad in a frilly blue dress. Although she didn't tower over me like everyone else, she still had a few inches on me. Regardless, the fact that she was anywhere near my size harshly reminded me that I was now her equal.

She perked up at the sight of me. "Oh! Hi, Melody!"

"Uh... hewwo, Bwittany," I replied, feeling jealous of her ability to talk properly.

"Come on, let's play!" she eagerly declared before dashing back into her room.

I gave Laura a pleading look. She kneeled down and spoke to me quietly. "I'm sorry, but I don't want to disappoint her, you know? Play along for a while, and the meantime Cassie can tell me everything, so I won't have to bother you with more questions."

I indicated my discontent with a groan before trudging into Brittany's room. Laura sealed my fate by closing the door behind me.

Whereas Melody's room was mostly just a kid's place, Brittany's room very clearly belonged to a girl. It was decorated in soft feminine colours, mostly pink and white. I looked around and spotted a dollhouse, a small assortment of stuffed animals, some kid-sized plastic furniture, and the wardrobe where Brittany undoubtedly kept her various girly outfits. The thought of being expected to interact with these things was not pleasant.

"Ooh, let's play dress up!" Brittany said. Okay, no. Anything but that.

"Uh, no thanks..." I said.

"No?" Brittany seemed a bit taken aback. She approached the dollhouse. "Well... wanna play house then?"

I had to accept that. "Okay..."

"Alright! You can be be the mummy this time..."

Right. That was something little girls did. Pretend to be mothers... because that was what they intended to be someday. I shuddered a little. Was I going to end up being a mom? Was I going to want that, decades from now? How much of my old self would even be left by the time I'd grown up all over again?

I pushed those thoughts aside. I had a very long time before I'd really have to consider such things. Right now, I would focus on more immediate concerns.

"Hey!" Brittany's voice brought me back to reality. "Come on, I've got it all ready!"

I halfheartedly followed her lead for a while, moving the dolls around, acting out the mock conversations she started, and generally doing what she seemed to expect of me. She was less than fooled, however, and seemed to grow increasingly concerned over my lack of enthusiasm.

"Are you okay, Melody?" she eventually asked. "You're acting all funny..."

I should have been ready for that. Between Brittany having her sister's smarts and my reluctance to play with her, I knew she was going to get suspicious. Yet here I was feeling like a deer in the headlights, having no idea of what excuse I could make.

As luck would have it, though, Laura and Cassie came into the room just then.

"Are you having fun?" Laura asked. No. No, I was not.

"Laura, Melody is acting weird..." Brittany said, looking up at her sister.

"Oh, uh..." Laura averted her eyes, an indication of guilt that did not go unnoticed.

"You know something! Tell me!" Brittany pleaded.

"Well, er... it's a secret," Laura said anxiously, knowing better than to try and convince her sister there was nothing wrong.

"A secret?" Brittany pouted. She turned back to me. "Melody, are you keeping a secret?"

I nervously rubbed the back of my head.

"Aw, come on! Why would you tell Laura and not me?"

I stayed silent. Brittany began to look quite upset.

"Melody... I won't be angry... please tell me..."

I looked up at Laura and Cassie. Their expressions seemed to indicate that this was my call... if only because they didn't want to make it themselves.
112311111112122.title: The perceptive playmate

choices: Cassie takes me to the playground
1123111111121222.content:
"I no feew good, that's awwl," I said, making up a lie on the fly. I wanted to minimize the amount of people who knew my secret, even if it meant having to continue hanging out with Brittany whenever I went to visit Stephen and Laura. Besides, playing with Brittany would give me the much-needed experience for interacting with little girls for when school started. September was less than a month away, and I'd be starting kindergarten. While having to go through kindergarten again wasn't exactly a prospect I was eagerly anticipating, at least I would learn my basic skills like reading. I'd have to wait until first grade, however, to learn how to write and read a clock.

"Oh no! Do you have a cold?" Brittany inquired. I looked up at Laura and Cassie, hoping I could send visual cues to get their help on this. However, I wasn't completely familiar with making facial expressions, what with my new face and all.

"No, it's not like that," said Cassie, "Melody just... had surgery recently. But she's better now!"

"Oh..." said Brittany, the lie seeming to appease her. Thankfully, fooling five year old girls wasn't very tough.

"Well, we're going to the movies," said Laura. My eyes lit up. "Ooh! Bwing me pwease!"

Laura and Cassie exchanged a glance and then looked back at me. "We would, said Cassie, "It's just that we're seeing a PG-13 rated movie. You can't go since you're only four." I crossed my arms over my tiny chest and looked at my feet. Yet another restriction of being a little kid.

"It's okay, you can stay here and play with Brittany," said Laura. Oh joy. They would be gone for two hours at a minimum, so I would be stuck here playing with Brittany for at least the rest of the morning.

Cassie looked at me sympathetically and followed Laura out.

"Well we better keep playing!" said Brittany. She picked up her doll. I picked up mine, the mommy doll. As we played, I realized that in certain ways, my doll was like my avatar and the dollhouse an RPG world. I realized that being in Melody's body was kind if like that also.

We played for a long time. There was a digital clock in Brittany's room, but since I couldn't make sense if numbers anymore, I had no idea how much time was actually passing.

My doll was tending to the garden when I heard the front door open.

"Hey Melody, it's time to go home!" shouted Cassie, and walked into the room a second later. I ran up to her and hugged her leg really tight. "Okay!" I exclaimed a little too excitedly.

"Bye, Brittany," said Cassie, and she led me out. I clutched her hand the whole way to the car.

"Now, what do you say to the mall?" asked Cassie, as she strapped me into my carseat and buckled it up tight. "Yeah!" I exclaimed.

I fell asleep on the way there. Being in a moving car was oddly calming to my four year old body. I awoke to Cassie unstrapping me from my carseat. She picked me up and put me on the ground. "Hold my hand," she said, "Parking lots can be dangerous." I held her hand, her seemingly huge fingers completely covering my tiny ones. I had to walk fast to keep up with her extra pace.

"Now, what kind if clothes do you want?" asked Cassie.

"Hmm," I said, "Not too giwwy, but not wike a boy!" Cassie smiled. "So you'll wear clothes made for girls as long as you don't have to wear dresses or skirts?" I nodded vigorously. "And no mowe pwincess shiwts!"

Cassie led me to a section labelled "Girls-Ages 3-5". I saw a lot of pink and purples, and shirts with random scribbles on them. I realized those scribbled were words.

"What dis say?" I asked, pointing to one purple shirt.

"It says 'Angel'," said Cassie. I looked at it, but just couldn't make sense of the random curvy lines. "What dis?" I asked, pointing at one if the especially weird letters. "That's a 'G'," said Cassie. All of a sudden, I started to get really frustrated. "Why can't I read this?" I said, stomping my foot as Melody was often apt to do. Cassie bent down and out her arms around me to comfort me. "You'll learn, Melody. Really soon, I promise."

"You pwomise?" I asked, beaming up at her.

"September's only a few weeks away," said Cassie, "And then school will start!" I smiled. "I can't wait fow schoow! "

"Your sister is so cute!" I looked around to see a very tall woman, even taller than Cassie, walking over to us.

"Why thank you!" exclaimed Cassie, then looked down at me. "You hear that, Melody? She thinks you're cute!" I just hid behind Cassie's leg. "She's just shy," said Cassie. I looked at the floor as I held on to Cassie's leg.

The woman and Cassie kept chatting, and Cassie told me to pick out some clothes. I was more interested in finding out what the shirts with writing said, so I gathered up as many as I could to bring back to Cassie.

Finally, I brought back the stack and asked Cassie what each of them meant.

"What dis say?"

"Daddy's Little Girl."

"Dis?"

"Princess."

"How bout dis?"

"Jewel."

"She has such a desire to learn! So wonderful!" said the woman. Cassie looked at me. "Melody, this is Jan. She's a kindergarten teacher, and you might have her this year!"

I looked up at the woman. "Youw a teachew?" She nodded happily.

"Wiw you teach me how to wead?"

Jan smiled. "Of course I will, dear." I hugged her leg. "Fank you Fank you Fank you!" I said breathlessly.

"So Melody, are these the clothes you want?" asked Cassie. I nodded. "Kay, let's go pay then. It was great meeting you, Mrs. Driver."

"The pleasure's all mine," the teacher said, and we were on our way.

112311111112122212.title: You cry and Cassie comes to help you

1123111111122.content:
I grit my teeth at the sight of Amelia waiting to torment me.

"Hey, Melody," she said, "Did you get bored of your big brother's games already? Come to play with your dollies instead?"

I did not have the patience for this.

"Amewia! Get outta my woom!" I demanded. I wasn't comfortable claiming ownership, but I couldn't order people out of the room if it wasn't mine, could I? For that matter, this was now the only place I could claim any sort of authority.

"That's right, this is your room now." Amelia gave me that mocking smile that had become far too familiar recently, and started walking around and pointing at things. "This is your bed with your little teddy bear, these are your dollies, this is your shelf of picture books and bedtime stories, here's where you keep your little dresses..."

"Shaddaaap!" I whined, doing that little stomp again. I was not helping myself. Thankfully, someone arrived who could.

"Amelia! Leave your sister alone!" Mom said sternly as she entered the room. "Honestly, can't you take anything seriously? David and Melody have just had their whole lives turned upside down. The least you could do is have a little respect."

I was tempted to add that that Amelia should just be glad I hadn't swapped with her, but I knew she was. She was just expressing it in the worst possible way.

"I was just showing her around," she said dismissively as she left. As if she knew Melody's room any better than I did.

I looked around and sighed. I had to admit Amelia had gotten to me. Everything I saw was a reminder of what I'd become and how far it was from what I'd been.

"Melody, honey? Are you alright?" Mom asked with genuine concern. Not knowing what to say, I wandered over to the bookshelf and fixed my eyes on one of the picture books. Might as well get started on relearning how to read.
1123111111122.title: Sisterly hate

11231111111221.content:
Pulled out the first picture book that caught my eyes out of the book shelf and held it up to Mom. "I need help reading" I tried to say, but because of Melody's wisp it came out as "I neid hewp weadin" much to my annoyance. Regardless, Mom clearly understood my words as she lifted me up into her arms, giving me a warm, comforting smile.
"OK sweety" she softly said to me as she sat down on Melody's - or rather MY bed, placing me on her lap as she held the picture book in front of me and began to read.

As I expected, the picture book was so basic and devoid of any narrative or ideas other than "The sky is blue" or "The grass is green" that my teenage boy mind would clearly fall asleep just reading it. However I was no longer a teenage boy, I was now a 4 year old little girl trying to imitate the words of my Mother as she read the picture book. It was a rather surreal experience, knowing that one half of me was way too old for this sort of stuff while the other half was learning something "new" here.

After she finished reading the last page of the picture book, Mom looked down at me and said, "You know, I read this very same book to you when you were Melody's age".
"Rweally?" I said as I looked up at my mother's face.

"It was so many years ago, but I remember it as if it was just yesterday" Mom said to me, "You and Casandra were always very excited to hear me read these picture books to you two. It was always so cute to see you two try to read the words on your own, and it always put a smile on my face when one of y'all would successfully read a word". She had a warm smile on her face as she said these words to me.

"Mommy?" I said

"Yes dear?"

"Tis sdil fwelz zo swange" I said to Mom, who proceeded to set the book down and hug me a little tighter.

"Melody, I know this is very hard for you sweetheart, being forced to live someone's life. Especially since it's your little sister whose body you ended up getting stuck in. But just know that we are all here for you, even David is here for you" Mom said to me

"Alexia's enjoin bakin vun ov me zo" I retorted in my little sister's cutesy voice

"Well Mommy and Daddy will make sure that mean old Alexia won't pester you, sweetheart" Mom said to me in a cutesy voice that, to be honest, sort of made me chuckle. "What I'm trying to say dear is to try to think of this in a positive light" She added.
"Buh houw?" I said
"Try thinking of this as a new opportunity dear. Maybe like one of those video games you used to play where you create a character and that character has their own roles and traits to experiment with" Mom said to me.
I gave it some thought as I sat in my mother's embrace. She is right that trying to remain being David in my new body would just make this more difficult for me to cope with my predicament. And I don't really like the idea of trying to perfectly mimic Melody's personality. It would be best to treat this as a new character; as much as I want to cling on to my old life, I need to accept that this is my new life and make of this new life that I can. The only issue is who am I going to be? If I can't be David anymore and I don't want to just turn into old Melody, then who am I, this new Melody.
I merely left my train of thought there as I gave my mother a nod. "Ow-Kay" I said to Mom, "Ial twie".

Mom set me aside as she put up the picture book, returning to tuck me in what was now my bed. She plants a kiss on my forehead, telling me "Goodnight Melody". After she left my room and close the door, it didn't take long before Melody's body succumbed to slumber, as I snoozed peacefully in bed.

- One Month Later -
A month had past since the operation, and I had gotten somewhat used to living in my little sister's body. Sure speaking in Melody's lisp was still somewhat annoying for me, but I've learned to ignore it (for the most part). While my teenage boy mind still somewhat refuses to accept the change in the family status quo, I have completely accepted the fact that just about everything and everyone is towering over my small body. There was something rather thrilling about it to be honest - trying to see all this in a positive light, I took it as being sort of an adventure; almost like I was thrust into another world and my goal was to adapt to this new world. Besides, being so small meant I could enjoy piggy back rides.

Alexia was still being such a "big meanie" (I am also trying to think in simpler terms that Melody's 4 year old brain would understand), but it wasn't too bad since she had to spend most of the day at school. I on the other hand didn't have to go to school since Melody's body still wasn't old enough to enter Kindergarten. Unfortunately though Cassandra and Melody had to go to school as well, the latter who has to spend even more time at school for tutoring (in order to be able to more steadily transfer into the high school setting). And "Daddy" spent most of the day at work, so it was usually just me and "Mommy" at home.

Usually after breakfast, "Mommy" would give me a bath - while I had kept insisting that I could bathe myself, "Mommy" told me that I wasn't old enough to be able to bathe myself and needed adult supervision. This morning however, instead of the usual "running away in my underwear" routine, I "admitted defeat" and let "Mommy" bathe me without causing any trouble - could she of at least let me dry myself though???...... On the other hand, I was still able to dress myself - however even that was taken over by "Mommy" as she would always choose what clothes I would wear - sometimes she would even try to force me to wear something "girly".

However, once all the whole ordeal was over, "Mommy" allowed me to play or watch TV. I didn't really like to watch TV all that much - now that I was in my little sister's body I could no longer watch the shows I had liked as a teenage boy; instead it was Sesame Street for me. At first I wasn't too fond of the idea of watching a "baby show", but once I gave it a try I found that within a few minutes I had become completely engrossed in the show; even though my mind was telling me that I was too old for this kind of stuff, the toddler brain that housed my mind found all the colorful characters and songs a novelty. Often I would find myself singing along with all the characters and be engaged whenever they had something to teach me - they would even help me learn how to read (although it's still a little hard).
After around 2 episodes of Sesame Street ("Mommy" only allows me an hour of TV a day in order to make me go play), I would usually go up to "my room" to find something to play with. As much of the brain that housed my mind was that of Melody's, I just couldn't get myself into playing with Barbie Dolls or anything girly like that. I know Melody was always into that kind of stuff, but in all honesty I was more fond of dressing up - or rather "rwole-pwayin" as I keep insisting to everyone. Now I wasn't really one to dress up as a princess, rather I was into "roleplaying" as a Cowgirl Sheriff, a superhero, and even try to "roleplay" "grown-up work" such as banking, running a store (I "sold" plastic items to Melody's stuffed animals), play house (playing as Mommy taking care of the baby stuffed animal), and even the occasional "tea party".. Although I will admit that every now and then I would dress up as the "pretty princess" with the stuffed animals as "my brave bodyguards".
Today I had decided to "roleplay" in a Wonder Woman costume to fight bad guys - in this case I used the Barbie dolls as the bad guys - in order to stop them from stealing all the tea from the tea party.

By the time I had "saved the day", I heard another cry for help - actually it was "Mommy" calling me that it was time for lunch. I ran down the stairs to the kitchen, still in my Wonder Woman costume as "Mommy" noticed.
"Were you able to save the day from those 'evil' Barbie dolls 'Wonder Woman'" she playfully asked me as she knelt down to me.
"Yith!! Ze Twea pawti waz awble to pwoseed wizout animwoe twouba" I exclaimed as I posed triumphantly in front of "Mommy".
"Mommy" then grinned
"You know, isn't Wonder Woman technically a "pretty princess" also?" she said, at which I stomped my feet and playfully pouted that Wonder Woman was a "Warrior princess" and that it didn't count because she's a superhero, which made "Mommy" giggle.
"Well in that case, aren't superheroes supposed to be able to - " before she finished that sentence she lifted me up , "FLY UP UP AND AWAY!!". She held me up high as I acted like I was flying for a few seconds, afterwards setting me down into my table booster seat. For lunch she made me a small bowl of mac and cheese along with a plate of carrots - I would only pretend to not want to eat the veggies only to eat my serving by the time lunch time was over. Of course, being in Melody's body, no matter how hard I tried I would usual end up making some kind of mess (this time I was able to keep my costume clean though) - hence whenever I had cereal for breakfast "Mommy" would always spoon feed me.....
After I had finished my lunch and "Mommy" was done wiping my face clean, that was when "Mommy" said that she is going to the store pretty soon so I would be going with her. I didn't really feel like going to the store, I wanted to play some more.
"Buh Mommy, I wanna pway som mwoe" I whined
"Well I can't leave you here all by yourself" "Mommy said
"Buh I ben by mysef befow" I retorted
"That was when you were a 16 year old boy, dear. Now you're way too young to be left by yourself" "Mommy" reminded me
"Ie knoe....."
"Also, technically your nap time is pretty soon if I recall" "Mommy" said with a grin
NO WAY WAS I GOING TO HAVE A NAP, I'M NOT TIRED
"Buh Imma not tired!!! I wanna goe to ze store wiz you" I exclaimed
"What happened to wanting to stay home" "Mommy" said
"I chjanjj mie mwind" I insisted
"But remember that nap time will be after the store dear. Promise" "Mommy added
"Pwomith" I responded, while also putting on a smile. "Buh canna at weast ztaie in my cozduem?" I asked?
"Mommy" give my question a few seconds of thought before she responded with ____
112311111112212.title: One month later

11231111111222.content:
"I'ww be okay, Mommy," I eventually said. "I jutht... want thome time awone."

"Well... if you need anything, just shout..." With that, Mom left, closing the door behind her, and I was alone in my new home for the first time.

I picked up the picture book I'd been staring at and opened the thick pages. A-P-P-L-E... apple. That just about made sense, but it took a lot of effort. I had a long way to go.

I spent the rest of the day mostly moping around in my new room, thinking about... not much, really, as I was a bit scared to think too hard.

The next day I woke up to Mom saying, "Melody! Time to get up!"

The proximity of her voice made me realise she was talking to me. I opened my eyes to the relatively unfamiliar surroundings of Melody's room.

"Bluhh," was all I could manage, briefly lifting my head before slamming it back down on the pillow.

"Come on, sleepyhead! Everyone else is up already!"

I just kept looking at her through half-shut eyes. She sighed.

"Look, I know you're overwhelmed," Mom said. "It can't be easy to wake up and face having to live someone else's life. But we're all here to support you. There's nothing to be scared of."

I reluctantly dragged myself out of bed.

"Good girl. Get dressed and we'll meet you downstairs." Mom left the room.

I groggily began looking through Melody's clothes. At least this time I could pick what to dress myself in. I didn't particularly like my options, though. I rummaged through various bits of girly attire before coming across a purple T-shirt and a pair of pink shorts. Well, I could do a lot worse. The shirt had something written on it, but of course I couldn't decipher what it said. I was probably better off not knowing.

Once dressed, I made my way down the still-humongous stairs and into the kitchen, finding the rest of the family waiting for me.

"Ah, here you are! Good morning!" Mom said as I looked up to watch her pour cereal into a bowl.

"Morning, sis!" Melody greeted me with my old voice.

"Hey, Melody," Cassie said somewhat sullenly.

"Up you go!" Mom lifted me up and put me on my chair. Then she picked up the bowl of cereal and sloshed it around with a spoon as she walked back to me. Great, she was going to spoon feed me. And judging by how difficult yesterday's dinner was, it wouldn't be wise to object.

Everyone in the room shot a pre-emptive glare at Amelia. She turned her head away, trying her best to look innocent.

"Eat up, dearie!" Mom said, offering me a spoonful of cereal. I reluctantly allowed it into my mouth and started chewing.

"Now, Melody," Mom said as she continued to feed me, "Your father and I were thinking it would be a good idea for you and David to spend some time together out of the house. Maybe you could go shopping, give yourself a bit of a makeover. I'm sure you'd feel better then."

"Yeah, that sounds good," Cassie chimed in. "I mean, you're Melody now, but you're not the same Melody. You can do what you want with your new self. If you get a new look, I think this'll all start making more sense for all of us."

That made sense. If I put my own mark on Melody's body, I could claim some of my identity back. I nodded, and Cassie smiled.

"And maybe then I can actually believe this is happening..." Dad added.

By the time I was done eating, Melody was standing up and fidgeting around, eager to get moving. She watched me get out of my chair and grinned. "Let's go, Melody! I can't wait to get out there and buy stuff!"

"Well, if you're ready, I guess you can go right away. I think the two of you together can handle everything," Mom said. She looked down at me. "Just keep an eye on your brother, Melody. Don't let him do anything irresponsible. And on that note... listen to your sister, David. She'll know what she's talking about."

"Right, right," Melody said. "You can teach me how to be... uh, me. We'll be fine. Let's go!" With that, she took off for the front door.

I was about to follow when Cassie stopped me. "Hey, if there's anything you need, call us, okay?" I nodded, opting not to point out it might be a challenge for either me or Melody to use a phone. "And when you get back... talk to me, okay? I want to hear everything that's on your mind."

"Uh-huh," I replied. "When I get back, I be new Mewody. Den we tawk."

"Thank you. Now get out there and face the world... Melody."

As I left the room, I quickly became determined to stay true to what I just said. I told myself that by the end of the day, I'd have a better sense of who I was and what I was going to do with myself.
11231111111222.title: Mutual babysitting
